title: Fed's Powell Says Economy Faces Long, Uncertain Recovery
summary: It will be hard for public to be 'fully confident' without a coronavirus vaccine, central bank chairman says. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said in an interview broadcast on Sunday that the U.S. economy could take more than a year to recover from the coronavirus-induced shock.

title: Cuomo Taps Private Advisers in Coronavirus Response, Stirring Critics
summary: Governor has enlisted Michael Bloomberg, Bill Gates and Eric Schmidt to help lead new efforts. As New York weathers the coronavirus crisis, Gov. Andrew Cuomo has enlisted the help of a trio of billionaires to trace the spread of the disease and think through how the state will look in the future.

title: Mexican Government Moves to Tighten Grip on Electricity Market
summary: New rules affecting renewable-power projects are criticized for favoring the country's state-owned utility. MEXICO CITY-The Mexican government moved to seize more control of the country's electricity market, affecting dozens of renewable-energy projects worth more than $6 billion at the same time the country faces a sharp recession because of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: No Swimming at New York City Beaches as Summer Nears
summary: Coronavirus to keep people out of the water; mayor says it is possible the ban will end later in season. New York City won't permit swimming at its beaches over Memorial Day weekend and in the coming weeks to try to slow the spread of the new coronavirus, but the ban could be lifted later this summer, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Sunday.

title: First Named Tropical Storm Forms in Atlantic Ahead of Hurricane Season
summary: Two weeks before the Atlantic hurricane season officially begins, Tropical Storm Arthur has formed off the southeast U.S. coast and is heading toward North Carolina. Two weeks before the Atlantic hurricane season officially begins, Tropical Storm Arthur has formed off the southeast U.S. coast and is heading toward North Carolina.

title: As West Cautiously Reopens, Infection Clusters Appear in Asia
summary: Authorities in U.S. explore a safe restart, but some countries that lifted measures face new clusters of Covid-19. While the U.S. and other Western countries continued to take steps to reopen their economies after months of coronavirus lockdowns, Asian countries that enacted aggressive measures early in the pandemic were battling new clusters of contagion.

title: Faithless Electors and the Will of the People
summary: If there's a risk here of post-Election Day "chaos," it's a chaos that the Constitution fully anticipates.. Regarding your editorial "'Faithless Electors' at the Supreme Court" (May 13), one can only sympathize with the contortions now required of staunch constitutional originalists as they recoil from the idea that state electors should have discretion in voting for the president, as the Framers clearly intended (see Sai Prakash's same-day op-ed "'Faithless' Electors Are Faithful to the Constitution").

title: Public, Personalized Medicine Have Their Place
summary: Public health is not the same as practicing medicine. One is dedicated to the prevention of disease and the other to its treatment. Both are important.. Regarding "Has Personalized Medicine Been a Wrong Turn?" (Review, May 9): Public health is not the same as practicing medicine. One is dedicated to the prevention of disease and the other to its treatment. Both are important but should not be seen as interchangeable. A physician doesn't choose a treatment because it's best for the population. Instead the physician's responsibility is to take all of the data available and apply it to the individual patient. It is a mistake to assume every patient will have the same outcome with the same therapy, just as it is a mistake to assume all disease should be preventable. Luckily with technology like genomics and artificial intelligence, we have more tools than ever before to ensure we make the best choices for all patients.

title: Lockdowns, Fear and Those Who Know Best
summary: The left and many in the media are distraught that some deplorables are protesting and violating social distancing guidelines.. Joseph Sternberg sees the 2020 U.S. presidential contest as turning into a moral crusade that poisons reasonable disagreements with unreasonable fears ("The Coronavirus and Project Fear 3.0," Political Economics, May 8). Britain's anti-Brexit politicians introduced Project Fear to scare voters out of supporting a withdrawal from the European Union, and shortly thereafter Democrats tried to scare Americans by portraying Donald Trump as a wannabe dictator, mad man and puppet of Vladimir Putin. Mr. Sternberg believes that Covid-19 opens the door now for Project Fear 3.0, as Democrats stake out the moral high ground of draconian lockdown safety versus the immoral push by Republicans to reopen stalled economies too quickly.

title: Should Florida Bail Out New York?
summary: A comparative look at population growth and spending over 10 years.. Democrats want a $915 billion budget bailout for states and cities, and the leading lobbyist is New York Governor Andrew Cuomo. His main public antagonist on the subject is Florida Senator and former Governor Rick Scott. Both men were first elected Governor in 2010, so let's do the math to consider which state has managed its economy and finances better over the last decade.

title: Hopeful News in Afghanistan
summary: A power-sharing deal will mean a united front against the Taliban.. The news has been grimmer than usual in Afghanistan, including last week's terror attack on a Kabul maternity ward that killed 26 women, children and babies. But the weekend brought a glimmer of progress as the country's main non-Taliban political rivals agreed to a power-sharing deal.

title: California Defines Testing Down
summary: Ignoring faculty, the UC president wants to drop the SAT and ACT.. As higher education braces for the impact of coronavirus, the nation's largest university system is poised to undermine the value of its own degrees by dropping admissions testing for political reasons.

title: Team Obama's Unmasking Dodge
summary: Biden, Clapper and Brennan serve up dubious answers.. The media are mostly ignoring the news that 39 Obama officials sought to read the transcripts of Michael Flynn's conversations with foreigners, but here and there they've asked a question. The unpersuasive answers suggest there's more to learn.

title: Lockdown Puts Brazilian Lives at Risk
summary: Ecuador is cited as a cautionary coronavirus tale, but halting economic activity didn't help.. Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro opposes the stringent lockdown some state governors have imposed on the Brazilian economy, and for weeks he's been battling political opponents who favor it. On Friday his health minister resigned but what is more important is that the arguments to open with common-sense precautions are gaining ground internationally.

title: Some Republicans Object to Trump's Firing of State Department Watchdog
summary: Lawmakers point to 2008 law that requires president to detail reasons for removing inspector general. WASHINGTON-Some Republican lawmakers are raising objections to President Trump's decision to fire State Department Inspector General Steve Linick, arguing that he didn't give Congress a sufficient justification for the removal.

title: Economy Week Ahead: Japan, Cares Act, Purchasing
summary: Global health crisis continues to affect world's economies. Economic news out this week will reflect more fallout from the coronavirus pandemic and policy makers' efforts to respond.

title: Who's Looking Out for Main Street?
summary: Treasury and the Fed seem more concerned about not losing money than getting relief to small businesses.. Small and midsize businesses have been hit hard by the pandemic, but they aren't getting the help they need. Why, when the Cares Act provides direct assistance to the Treasury to assist these firms? Congress now has a chance to get to the bottom of it. On Tuesday the Senate Banking Committee will hold its first quarterly hearing on the Cares Act. It will hear from Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell. Three questions should frame the hearing:

title: How Biden Can Win Over Progressives
summary: He'll need to take a stand against corporate money in politics-corruption-and prove that he means it.. How can Joe Biden win over progressives? Here are three tips for his supporters: Stop insulting us, stop blaming us for losing an election you haven't even lost yet, and ask us what we want.

title: Why We're Suing the SEC
summary: In the name of speeding up its work, the agency is putting individual investors at risk of identity theft.. Mom-and-pop investors didn't cause the 2010 market blip known as the "flash crash," but the Securities and Exchange Commission is suggesting as much to justify a new government program that will collect and store the most sensitive personal information of every U.S. retail investor in a single database. This exposes investors to a high risk of identity theft. That's why the American Securities Association, which I lead, is suing the commission.

title: Finally, the Low Prices We Deserve
summary: The economic crash is 'unflating' decades-old bubbles in several stagnant industries.. Stanford Health Care cut employees' pay 20% in late April. JetBlue Airways halved top executive compensation. A huge glut of oil, wine, airline seats and even lobsters means prices are plummeting. And whoa, Apple 's new iPhone SE is $399, quite a change from its $999 models. It's starting: April's consumer-price index was down 0.8%, but get ready for steady price declines and a long trip down that escalator. Like a released balloon going pffflllttt in slo-mo. Let's call it the Great Unflation.

title: Searching on Foot for My White Whale
summary: Even amid lockdown, an empty Brooklyn street proves to be an elusive quarry.. Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: 'No Filter' Review: Picture Perfect
summary: A decade after its founding, Instagram, with a little help from Facebook, has more than a billion users, many of them 'influencers.'. Since its launch 10 years ago, Instagram has gone from a Silicon Valley startup to an ever-present factor in daily life for more than a billion users. In "No Filter," Sarah Frier, a technology reporter for Bloomberg, tells the story of how co-founders Kevin Systrom and Mike Krieger, two 20-something Stanford grads working in San Francisco, created a mobile app that became a social network that became an advertising behemoth. Previous social-media services such as Facebook had risen to prominence primarily on the PC desktop. Messrs. Systrom and Krieger launched on the iPhone. The app was "mobile-first" from the start, and the idea was simple-just take a picture of your life and post it so your friends and others could see.

title: Silicon Valley's Next Big Office Idea: Work From Anywhere
summary: Tech companies once wooed talent with over-the-top campuses. Now they are looking to keep workers happy by offering flexibility. Four years ago, Aaron Levie moved Box Inc., the fast-growing cloud-computing company he co-founded, into a new, red-brick building with its logo on the facade. Box decked it out with all the trappings of Silicon Valley: a sleek cafeteria, common areas with orange hammocks, and a bar built from a converted Volkswagen van with kombucha and cold-brew coffee on tap.

title: Cut Through the Fog of Coronavirus War
summary: The CDC needs to streamline and publish clinical data to help doctors on the front lines.. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention made its first definitive statement last week describing a rare but disturbing condition in children related to Covid-19. Doctors in the U.K. first reported in April a spike in previously healthy children presenting with features similar to another rare condition, Kawasaki disease, whose symptoms include rash and fever and, later in its progression, inflammation of blood vessels.

title: Oil Becomes a Risky Game for Saudis
summary: Lower prices put U.S. producers at a disadvantage, but they also cost Riyadh and imperil ties with the U.S.. President Trump is playing a tense poker game with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. The stakes are America's oil industry and the U.S.-Saudi alliance.

title: Israel Swears In Fragile New Government, as Friction Looms
summary: Unity deal ends a yearlong political deadlock but parties disagree over issues including West Bank annexation and judicial power. TEL AVIV-Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's new unity government was sworn in Sunday, cementing a fragile political alliance with former rival Benny Gantz to end more than one year of political stalemate in the country.

title: Pandemic Review Still in Balance as China, U.S. Weigh Response
summary: U.S. wants an independent inquiry to target China's coronavirus-related actions. More than 100 countries, led by the European Union and Australia, have backed a resolution to independently review the global response to the coronavirus pandemic and the question of whether the World Health Organization acted to the best of its limited powers to contain the disease.

title: Obama Takes Aim at Coronavirus Response
summary: Former president doesn't mention any U.S. leaders by name but says they 'aren't even pretending to be in charge'. WASHINGTON-Former President Barack Obama returned to the national stage on Saturday, delivering a pair of virtual commencement addresses in which he criticized the response by some U.S. leaders to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: We're Out of Toilet Paper, Hand Sanitizer-and Golf Pushcarts?
summary: Once-disparaged device is an item everybody wants after courses ban caddies and motorized carts to fight coronavirus. Robbie Gould, the San Francisco 49ers' kicker, couldn't believe his luck when a local store told him it had a line on a product he desperately wanted. The NFL star finally had his very own golf pushcart.

title: Army Deploys Videogames to Reach Recruits
summary: Dedicated esports team uses tournaments as safe way to connect with prospective soldiers during coronavirus. Army recruiters, unable to head to high schools and set up booths at state fairs because of the coronavirus, are turning to videogame tournaments to reach prospective soldiers.

title: Phyllis George, Female Sportscasting Pioneer, Dies at 70
summary: The former Miss America joined CBSs 'The NFL Today' and served as the first lady of Kentucky. Phyllis George, the former Miss America who became a female sportscasting pioneer on CBS's "The NFL Today" and served as the first lady of Kentucky, has died. She was 70.

title: Afghan President Agrees to Share Power With Rival
summary: Deal ends a monthslong feud over the outcome of a disputed presidential election that had threatened to derail U.S.-backed peace efforts. KABUL-Afghanistan's President Ashraf Ghani and his political rival Abdullah Abdullah signed a power-sharing agreement on Sunday, ending a monthslong feud over the outcome of last year's disputed presidential election that had threatened to derail U.S. efforts to extricate itself from its longest war.

title: New York City Teachers Push for Specific Safety Measures Before Schools Reopen
summary: Students may see smaller class sizes, physical distancing and staggered days when they return. For Michael Frank, a high-school social studies teacher in New York City, effective social distancing isn't anything new. Before the coronavirus prompted the city's schools to close and migrate to remote learning in March, Mr. Frank was giving mini-lessons to some students on the topic.

title: Chinese Ambassador to Israel Found Dead in His Home
summary: Du Wei, 57, was a career diplomat who had arrived in Israel in February. China's ambassador to Israel was found dead Sunday in his residence north of Tel Aviv, Israeli officials said.

title: India's Coronavirus Crisis Spurs a New Look at Self-Reliance
summary: Pandemic sparks new search for solutions, and the resurgence of talk of self-sufficiency; 'Let's be vocal for local'. NEW DELHI-The coronavirus pandemic has pushed India's jobs crisis from bad to worse, leading the government to take a new look at an old solution: self-reliance.

title: What I've Learned About Investing in the Time of Coronavirus
summary: Our columnist grades himself on four big market calls he made as the pandemic unfolded. This year has compressed market experience that usually takes a decade or more into five seemingly-endless months, providing a great opportunity to learn from both mistakes and successes.

title: Why You're Going to See More Animation (Thanks, Pandemic)
summary: As traditional TV production struggles, the medium has steamed ahead, in some cases saving fall lineups or enhancing live-action episodes. Actor Eric Bauza has transformed a walk-in closet in his Los Angeles home into a makeshift recording studio. On a recent morning, he opened up the audio software on his laptop, joined his producers, director, voice director and production managers on a Zoom videoconference, and launched into the spluttering tones of Daffy Duck: "There's a frog in my throat!"

title: J.C. Penney Needs Quick Bankruptcy Exit
summary: The 118-year-old department-store chain has proposed splitting up its retail and real-estate holdings through a bankruptcy process. The clock is ticking for J.C. Penney Co. , which is racing to settle with creditors quickly enough to convince them it can once again make money selling clothing, cosmetics and cookware to another generation of Americans.

title: Companies Hope Extending Relief to Borrowers Now Can Ward Off Defaults Later
summary: Programs offering support on credit-card and auto loans during the coronavirus pandemic strive for balance. As borrowers get a break on paying down credit-card, vehicle and other consumer loans, banks and financial institutions extending the relief face a balancing act in the months ahead.

title: Big Consulting Firms Push Back Start Dates for New Hires
summary: They cite reduced current business, visa issues and a hesitance to uproot people. Some of the largest consulting firms, including McKinsey & Co. and Boston Consulting Group, are pushing back start dates for some of their newest hires.

title: The Science of Prayer
summary: Many people are praying now, and scientists say the practice may boost mental health. Jillian Richardson has a new routine when she takes a walk. She puts on a mask, pops in her earbuds and heads out the door. Then she starts talking out loud.

title: Bets on Slow Economic Recovery Challenge Market Rally
summary: Investors increasingly believe that fallout from the coronavirus pandemic will last longer than they initially thought. Stocks recorded their biggest weekly percentage drop in nearly two months last week, a sign that recent gains are just one step of what many analysts say will be a long and painful recovery.

title: Kim Jong Un Disappeared From View, But North Korea's Problems Never Left
summary: Leader signals focus on the home front as Pyongyang faces economic strains, coronavirus threat. SEOUL-When Kim Jong Un emerged after weeks of questions over his health and whereabouts, the North Korean leader picked a visit to a fertilizer factory as the stage for his public return.

title: Photos of the Week
summary: Militants attack Afghan hospital, killing babies; FBI seizes Sen. Burr's cellphone in stock-trade probe; states further ease coronavirus restrictions and more. A nurse helps a patient in the intensive-care unit at the Scripps Mercy Hospital Chula Vista in Chula Vista, Calif. Hospitals in this border city south of San Diego are struggling to cope with a large number of Covid-19 patients, an influx they attribute to legal crossings from nearby Tijuana, one of Mexico's hardest-hit cities. 'I haven't seen any screening coming into the U.S. or going into Mexico,' said Melody Thomas, director of clinical services at the Scripps hospitals in Chula Vista and San Diego. About 25% of her patients come from Tijuana and the surrounding state of Baja California. Read more.

title: Saudi Sovereign-Wealth Fund Buys Stakes in Facebook, Boeing, Disney
summary: The fund also bought financial stocks, including Citigroup and Bank of America. In the coronavirus pandemic's financial fallout, Saudi Arabia's $300 billion sovereign-wealth fund has emerged as one of the world's biggest bargain hunters, taking minority stakes worth billions of dollars in American corporations.

title: Wary of U.S. Crude, Investors Bet on Gasoline and Brent
summary: U.S. gasoline demand is 'the big enchilada,' says one analyst. Wary of U.S. crude oil after prices sank below zero, investors are seeking different ways to profit from the energy market as pockets of the world economy emerge from lockdown.

title: College-Town Economy Shudders as Coronavirus Cancels Graduations, Campus Classes
summary: Resume Subscription. The coronavirus pandemic has turned vibrant college towns across the U.S. into vacant ones.

title: Leaders Emerge in Vaccine Race
summary: Drugmakers build capacity to make hundreds of millions of doses, while authorities discuss: Who will get it first?. Governments and drugmakers are weighing how to roll out coronavirus vaccines, including reserving the first batches for health-care workers, as several shots race to early leads.

title: More Complexity, Fewer Customers: Auto Industry Tries to Reopen
summary: Supply chain sputters back from coronavirus crisis in fits and starts; 'It's like figuring out a jigsaw puzzle'. Like many in the U.S. auto industry this month, Peter Anthony is busy trying to get his auto-supply business running again after a multiweek shutdown.

title: U.S. Expected to Revise Small-Business Aid Program
summary: Changes likely to give firms more flexibility and time to spend funds from the Paycheck Protection Program. WASHINGTON-Lawmakers and government officials are preparing to make significant changes to the Paycheck Protection Program, amid cooling demand for government-backed loans and criticism from business owners who say they can't tap the funds.

title: Fearful and Wary, Italian City Ravaged by Coronavirus Slowly Re-Emerges
summary: Resume Subscription. BERGAMO, Italy-On a recent day, Juri Ambrosioni sold 250 coffees at his takeout place in the center of this northern Italian city, with patrons wearing face masks and standing patiently in line for their espresso or cappuccino fix.

title: Magic Johnson Makes Another Assist-to the Small Business Aid Program
summary: Former Laker is looking for ways to help hard-hit minority communities during the coronavirus crisis. Citing concerns that minority-owned businesses are being overlooked, Earvin "Magic" Johnson said his EquiTrust Life Insurance Co. will provide $100 million in capital to fund loans through the Small Business Administration's Paycheck Protection Program.

title: Large Blast Inside Los Angeles Building Injures 11 Firefighters
summary: Explosion leaves several in critical, but not life-threatening condition, city officials said. Eleven firefighters were injured Saturday evening by a large explosion inside a commercial building in downtown Los Angeles.

title: China Told Labs to Destroy Coronavirus Samples to Cut Risks
summary: A Chinese senior official says domestic law has clear rules for the handling of highly pathogenic samples. A senior Chinese official appeared to confirm Secretary of State Mike Pompeo's allegation that Beijing had told labs in the country to destroy coronavirus samples in early January but slammed his characterization as misleading.

title: Amazon to Reopen French Warehouses After Deal With Unions
summary: The online retailer had closed its warehouses on April 16 after a court found in favor of unions that had complained about working conditions. PARIS- Amazon.com Inc. said it plans to begin reopening its warehouses in France next week, after resolving a dispute over working conditions with workers' unions.
